Several actions have been taken to preserve historical landmarks in Rome, Italy. Some of these actions are:

1. The establishment of the Historical Centre of Rome - In 1980, the Italian government established the Historic Centre of Rome which includes most of the city's ancient landmarks.

2. Restoration projects – The Italian government has initiated and supported several restoration projects on ancient landmarks such as the Colosseum, the Roman Forum, and the Pantheon.

3. Protection laws – The Italian government has issued several laws to protect historical landmarks from decay and destruction. The most notable of them is the 1939 Law on Protection of Historic Monuments and Sites.

4. International collaborations – Italy has collaborated with international organizations such as UNESCO to protect and preserve its historical landmarks. In 1980, UNESCO declared the Historic Centre of Rome a World Heritage Site.

5. Private funds – Several private organizations and individuals have contributed to the preservation of historical landmarks by donating funds to initiate restoration projects. 

6. Limitation on tourism - The number of tourists visiting some of Rome's popular landmarks have been limited to preserve them. 

All these actions have contributed to the preservation of Rome's historical landmarks, which continue to attract tourists and serve as a testament to the city's rich cultural heritage.
